author: Michele Amoretti
title: By: Michele Amoretti

content:
A small correction:

When shall we find an explicit function requiring more than 3n gates? … “as soon as we have explicit dispersers for quadratic varieties.”

Actually, the authors of that paper and two others already proved an unconditional greater-than-3n lower bound for an explicit function using similar techniques: http://eccc.hpi-web.de/report/2015/166/. The point of their ITCS paper was that explicit quadratic dispersers imply a yet stronger lower bound.

author: Grigory Yaroslavtsev
title: By: Grigory Yaroslavtsev

content:
I really like this idea of a “session chair rant.” More conferences should do them.

Quite often in a conference, there are a handful of people in the audience who know exactly why the problem that the speaker is trying is solve is interesting. For the rest, it feels like the speaker is treating self-inflicted wounds.

Of course, most speakers try to set the context at the talk’s outset. Of course, most speakers are rubbish at setting said context.

Usually, a session chair’s job is policing time: a terrible waste of a top mind. Thus, it makes a great deal of sense for the chair to be tasked with providing context; or even simply to say that they feel completely lost.
